body:
As introduced in Module 1, open data sits at the heart of the open government movement. Open data presents significant economic, environment and social benefits, and is an integral part of delivering a first class foreign policy for the UK.

This module looks at the role of data in helping FCO to deliver their objectives around the world, and certain considerations to keep in mind when planning for data publication.

This module explores:

  • Data, information and knowledge
  • The role of data in the FCO
  • Open data at the FCO
  • Sensitive data at the FCO
  • Moving towards open at the FCO

title: The role of data in the FCO

body:
Transparency of information is a foundation of open government. But transparency alone is not enough to for the UK to maximise the wider economic, environment and social benefits.

This module looks at the evolution of global commitments to transparency, and the importance of open government, open data and the 'open by default' principle to transparency.

In this module we are going to explore...

  • The global transparency movement
  • Open government
  • Open data
  • Open by default
  • Case studies from around the world
title: Transparency and open data

body: Transparency sits at the heart of an open government. In 2011, the UK government was a founding member of the Open Government Partnership (OGP). The OGP is an international platform for reformers committed to making their governments more open, accountable and responsive to citizens.
title: The pillars of open government
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body: The goal of the transparency pillar is to promote increased access to information and disclosure about governmental activities.

_items.title: Participation
_items.body:
There are three main goals to the participation pillar:

  • Making policy formulation and decision-making more transparent.
  • Creating and using channels to solicit public feedback.
  • Deepening public participation in developing, monitoring and evaluating government activities

_items.title: Anti-corruption
_items.body: The anti corruption pillar aims to strengthen anti-corruption laws and ensure transparency in the management of public finances.

_items.title: Technological innovation
_items.body:
The pillar aims to support partners to developing accessible and secure online spaces to:

  • deliver services
  • engage the public
  • share information and ideas

body:
Openness in government can save money, reduce corruption, enable evidence-based decision making, strengthen people’s trust in government and encourage greater public participation in decision-making. 

Explore how being open can provide benefit in all 4 pillars below:
displayTitle: Case studies from around the world
title: Case studies from around the world

_items.title: Citizen participation
_items.body:
Open data allows citizens to see inside the workings of government, to monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account over their commitments, and participate in decision-making. When citizens are empowered with information, they can also co-create solutions to improve their daily lives.

Case studies

The Linida initiative, Indonesia, provides a platform to gather information on village assets and opportunities to improve socio-economic lives of villagers. Villagers use public information and produce their own data to engage with decision makers so that the local development policy and public service provision fulfill their priorities

The Participatory Monitoring Maputo platform, Mozambique- informs citizens about the need for proper waste removal and progress on waste removal, and aims to empower them to request services from the government through the use of a mobile app.

_items.title: Anti-corruption and fraud
_items.body:
The UK is committed to fighting corruption at home and abroad.  In 2016 the UK became the first country in the world to collect and publish who controls and benefits from companies in a structured format. Making data available on the beneficial owners of companies is important in the fight against corporate accountability.

Another way the UK government is tackling the perception of fraud is by publishing open data on government grant spending. In October 2017, the government introduced a platform allowing departments to share information on £100 billion worth of grants data from across government departments using a standard format developed by the 360Giving initiative.

Case studies

Making contracting and procurement more transparent eg Paraguay is using open contracting to improve spending on education. Information about education contracts unearthed a wider spending scandal that triggered a formal investigation and citizen pressure and reform of school spending.

changing the behaviour of public officials to be less wasteful eg the Municipal Money open data portal was launched in South Africa to inform citizens on their local authority’s financial performance and counter abuse of resources.

_items.title: Stimulating economic growth and facilitating trade
_items.body:
There is growing evidence that open data contributes to economic growth and trade by providing access to information on the business environment, and opening reducing information asymmetries so more small and medium businesses and compete for opportunities or enter new markets.

Case studies

Publishing government grant opportunities can enable a more diverse group of SMEs and businesses to compete in the market eg Spend Network provides insight and analysis on public procurement and finance data to help suppliers identify opportunities to bid for government grants

Improving trade connections between countries eg Labora is open data accelerator in Mexico- linking entrepreneurs working with open data to mentors, investors, data providers/regulators, and capacity building. With support of the UK Embassy and the ODI, the project has also facilitated exchanges between start-ups in UK and Mexico.

Helping businesses to comply with local and international regulations eg Better Regulation Delivery Office, Ukraine- uses open data to create tools that give users access to information about regulations in just a few clicks, such as requirements to start a business

_items.title: Crisis management
_items.body:
Open data is a critical resource when responding to natural or manmade crises. In emergency situations or in resource-constrained environments, open data may be combined and enriched with other sources of data. In scenarios where government open data is not available, volunteers may fill the gap in data collection. In particular, the OpenStreetMap community contribute and maintain data about roads, trails, cafés, railway stations, and much more, all over the world.

Case studies

Open data can help in crisis management through:

facilitating information flows: Humanitarian actors, service providers and government agencies sharing data during Ebola outbreak to strengthen service delivery

monitoring risk and assessing needs: Use of OSM and combining sources of data during Nepal earthquake

Coordinating responses to disasters for greater efficiency of resources.

_items.title: Open by default
_items.body: Principle one of both the G8 Open Data Charter and more recent global Open Data Charter: Open by default is the principle that everything should be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal, ethical or otherwise harmful reason why it should remain closed.

_items.title: Case studies
_items.body:
Canada- piloting an ‘open by default’ approach to releasing public sector information in 4 government departments (Canadian Heritage, Environment and Climate Change Canada, Natural Resources Canada, and Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat). The pilot promotes the proactive release of working information to provide a sample of the government’s scientific and cultural research for public researchers, businesses and curious citizens to use.

New Zealand- introducing a ‘Data Champions’ network to lead the release of open data across their agency or department. Data champions provide core entry points into an agency and ensure engagement both internally and externally with data users.

body:
A global transparency movement is growing, facilitated by technology and social media and fuelled by access to new information sources.

Transparency is when that the public should have access to government-held information and be informed of government proceedings. It is a hallmark of an ‘open government’.

According to the Transparency and Accountability Initiative (TAI), transparency is managing and publishint information that is:

  • relevant
  • accessible
  • timely
  • accurate
title: The global transparency movement

body: Data and information are different, although the two words are mistakenly used as synonyms. This section looks at the differences between these concepts, and the benefits of providing access to raw data for the FCO.
title: Data, information and knowledge

_items.title: Data
_items.body: Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived. Think of data as those location, images, descriptions, and maps that form the basis of information that can feed into a dataset on the location of FCO offices around the world.

_items.title: Information
_items.body: Information is processed data that has been given context. For example the total amount of expenditure on overseas development assistance (ODA) is actually information. The raw data that was used to put together this piece of information is likely to be multiple types of spending broken down by type, over a specific time period.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body: Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs. Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices. For example, creating a country needs assessment report based on multiple sources of information including current levels of expenditure on ODA and GDP.

body:
Not all data should be made open, especially where it contains sensitive data. If not treated sensitively, it can affect people's trust in data and in the responsible organisation.

There are legitimate reasons why some FCO data should not be published openly. Justifications may be made on the grounds of:
title: Sensitive data at the FCO

_items.title: National security
_items.body:
Transparency sometimes needs to be balanced against national security issues. There may be good reason not to disclose information such as defence or security assets, or location and timing of counter-terrorism exercises, which could damage capabilities or effectiveness of UK operations.

For example, publishing diplomatic telegrams which contain intelligence information regarding an unfolding political coup or sensitive policy advice to ministers could put British Nationals in the Territory in question under risk.

_items.title: Privacy and confidentiality
_items.body:
Data containing personally identifiable information (PII) should not be released widely to protect individuals.

However data can be published the data has been suitably anonymised in accordance with privacy legislation and internationally recognised standards.

For example consular reports containing data about the location of pickpocketing and theft incidents reported at airports might contain PII. However, if the data is anonymised, it could be useful to understand spikes in petty crime activity in different areas.

You can find out more about anonymisation in this online guide, or by getting in touch with the UK Anonymisation Network (UKAN)

_items.title: Commercially or market sensitive data
_items.body:
Commercially or market sensitive data may be damaging to the UK government or to a commercial partner if improperly accessed. Much commercial data may be time sensitive, with the potential harm caused by disclosure diminishing over time. For example, the sensitivity of data relating to interest rates is likely to diminish in this way as time passes.

Data on future transactions regarding dealings in the extractives industry are widely regarded as commercially sensitive as disclosure to the public could cause actual harm.

_items.title: Intellectual property
_items.body:
Publishing data which is protected by copyright or database rights may not be permitted under law. It is important to determine what intellectual property rights exist in the data before you consider opening it and publishing under an open licence.

For example, Flickr photos on FCO embassy events might not be capable of sharing and re-use because they haven't been shared with an open licence.

_items.title: Investigations
_items.body:
Data from investigations or civil or criminal proceedings could compromise public protection or enforcement activities, or prejudice court cases.

For example publishing the identify of persons being investigated for war crimes might put family members at risk.

body: Whilst the FCO already publishes some data openly, more could be released for the benefit of the FCO, wider government and citizens. In this section, we explore some of the questions that you can ask yourself when preparing to publish FCO data.
title: Moving towards open data

_items.title: 1) Is there an existing public commitment to publish the dataset?
_items.body:
Your first step is to check whether there is an existing requirement to publish that data. The FCO has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and an open data strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets. These have been selected based on utility to the FCO’s mission, and the PM’s Transparency Commitments of 2010-2011.

The list of datasets are regularly reviewed and added to. Many government departments maintain a data inventory to help with the process of prioritising data publication. Data inventories provide a full list of data assets collected and maintained by an organisation.

If the dataset in question is not listed, you should consider if the dataset could be open In accordance with the principle of ‘open by default’

_items.title: 2) Is there a reasonable justification to not share or disclose the dataset?
_items.body:
As we discussed in Module 1, ‘open by default’ means data should be open for everyone to access, unless there is a very good reason not to share. In the previous section, we discussed some of the possible justifications.

At this stage, consider whether any of these exceptions may apply. The UK government has a system for classifying sensitive information, which may help you make an assessment.

_items.title: 3) How to classify and license the dataset?
_items.body:
When deciding whether the dataset in question could be opened- it can be helpful to map the datasets that you have on the Open Data Institute's ‘Data Spectrum’.

The data spectrum categories data into open/shared/closed based on who can be granted access to the dataset, and how they are permitted to use the data.

You can find out more about using the Data Spectrum in this article.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Spectrum (learning edition) [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: 4) Check third party ownership and rights?
_items.body:
Before continuing, you should double check that the datasets you've listed are yours to publish or that you have the original data provider's permission (for example, if you are aggregating sources or anonymising).

If you aren't currently permitted to share the data more widely or open it, then it might be worth asking the provider and outlining the benefits to them.

_items.title: 5) What are the pros and cons?
_items.body:
If you have identified an opportunity to open a dataset, it is important to think about the benefits and practical blockers at this stage. For instance:

  • What are the benefits for your team and the FCO more broadly, for those who may want to innovate with your data, and for society as a whole?
  • Are there any changes are needed to your team's way of working, strategy or business plan? Do you have an accurate understanding of the process behind collecting and processing the dataset, so that it could be routinely updated?
  • Do you have the resources to make the data available (and maintain it) sustainably?
  • What are the quick wins – short-term activities that will demonstrate progress? This can be useful in getting support from others.

body: There are many benefits for FCO and other government departments to provide access to raw data, not just information or knowledge:
displayTitle: The role of data at the FCO: raw data
title: The role of data at the FCO: raw data
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: Lowest level  of abstraction
_items.body:
Data is the lowest level of abstraction. Raw data can always be turned into information and knowledge outputs, the reverse it not possible.

For example, data can be easily turned into percentages. However, percentages cannot be turned back into raw data without additional context such as the sample size.

_items.title: Easily repeated analysis
_items.body:
Responses to requests for information (like spending on aid) are more repeatable.

Raw data also provides the possibility for regular updating of analysis, whereas information only provides a snapshot at a point in time.

_items.title: Reduces costs
_items.body:
Reduces costs and level of staff effort over time. This is particularly relevant when dealing with FOI requests.

In the first six months after the proactive release of open data by South Australia's police department, 31% of FOI requests were sent directly to their open data portal, reducing the burden on staff.

_items.title: Increasing domestic transparency
_items.body: As a key government department, the FCO is is a strategic place to support the openness and transparency of government. This enables citizens to see how much governments around the world are receiving in revenues, and how much of that money is being re-invested in the economy.

_items.title: Increasing transparency in aid flows
_items.body: Publishing open data can help increase transparency in UK aid flows, so those people in developing countries can hold their governments to account for spending the aid effectively. This also allows people who give generously in the UK to see the impact their money makes.

_items.title: Encouraging transparency internationally
_items.body:
Having a strong open data agenda helps the FCO support the countries it works in to become more transparent and accountable.

For example, the UK Embassy in Bosnia and Herzegovina is working with a range of partners to strengthen the capacity for implementing open data in Bosnia and Herzegovina, even within a constrained political environment. Projects include producing an ‘open government’ guide for government and civil society representatives, supporting an open government working group leading advocacy efforts for Bosnia and Herzegovina to join the Open Government Partnership, and training civil servants from key Ministries to format and publish open data.

_items.title: Transparecy
_items.body:
Traditionally transparency has been the sole purpose of the Freedom of Information act (FOI). 

Open data is not the death of FOI, however it can both reduce the number of FOI requests and streamline to response to others. 

In Carlisle, publication of real-time business rates has reduced the number of FOI requests, saving the council up to £15,000 annually. (Source)

In 2009-2010 FOI requests were estimated to cost the Greater Manchester public bodies over £4 million a year. At the same time over 600 public officials a day were unable to find data they required for their jobs – costing over £8.5 million a year. DataGM was created to release and bring together in one place, solving both problems. (Source)

_items.title: Citizen Participation
_items.body:
Open data allows citizens to see inside the workings of government, to monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account and participate in decision-making.

The Linida initiative, Indonesia, provides a platform that villagers use to engage with decision makers so that the local development policy and public service provision fulfil their priorities

The Participatory Monitoring Maputo platform, Mozambique- informs citizens about the need for proper waste removal and progress on waste removal, and aims to empower them to request services from the government through the use of a mobile app.

_items.body:
Open data can help deliver new services to the public while driving efficiencies in the delivery of current public services.

Singapore is using open transport data and analytics to improve the commuting travel experience. Arrival times of buses are tracked using sensors installed in over 5,000 vehicles, to manage overcrowding and waiting times.

This data is then made available public and third party developers, who can put them to good use in creating people-centric transport solutions such as apps that helps wheelchair users find accessible routes.

title: Are you ready to lead in transparency and openness?

body:
The FCO is committed to open data. The department has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and an open data strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets including those related to aid, consular services and spending.

The FCO also makes use of a large amount of data and open data within internal activities, however challenges still exist in realising the benefits of a strong data strategy within the FCO.

This module looks at:

  • Data as a raw material
  • The benefits of data in the FCO
  • Supporting the FCO open data strategy
  • Dealing with sensitive data

title: The role of data in the FCO

displayTitle: Data is 'the new raw material of the 21st century'
title: Data is 'the new raw material of the 21st century'

body:
Raw data (sometimes called source data or atomic data) is data that has not been processed for use.

A distinction is sometimes made between data and information to the effect that information is the end product of data processing. Think of data as those location, images, descriptions, and maps that form the basis of information that can feed into a dataset on the location of FCO offices around the world.

Raw open data provides the possibility for regular updating of analysis by anyone, whereas information only provides a snapshot at a point in time.

Think of data like the raw food ingredients and information like a 'ready meal', both have their place but one is much more flexible than the other!
title: Data as a raw material

body:
Data plays an important role within a modern diplomatic service.  It is important for knowledge management, generating insights and intelligence, designing better public-facing services (eg up to date travel advice), ensuring proper resourcing, and informing better decisions.

Enabled by new technology, there is more opportunity for FCO staff to access and use different sources of data for decision making- including social media, big data and open data. The greater use of digital media and new technology for communications and engagement is referred to as ‘digital diplomacy’. Read more about the FCO’s commitments to digital transformation in ‘Future FCO’ report, and Diplomacy 2020.
displayTitle: The benefits of data in the FCO
title: The benefits of data in the FCO
instruction: Find out more about the important role of raw data in the FCO below:

_items.title: Crisis management
_items.body:
Publishing and making use of open data in crises response can ensure that a faster more effective response can be made.

Data is a critical resource when responding to natural or manmade crises. In emergency situations or in resource-constrained environments, having access to raw data is essential as you never know what crises will come next. 

Open data plays a key role in crises responses as it is the only form of data everyone can use.

In particular, the OpenStreetMap community is often at the heart of humanitarian response situations, be it in response to devastating earthquakes in Nepal or Haiti. 

Open data can also help facilitate information flows to help humanitarian actors, service providers and government agencies share data. Open data played a key role during Ebola outbreak to strengthen service delivery, monitoring risk and assessing needs.

_items.title: Consular services
_items.body:
The delivery of consular services is complex and multi-faceted. Collecting and using data more effectively can help evaluate the performance and cost of providing such services and identify potential ways to improve. 

The FCO already holds (and occasionally publishes) key consular performance statistics. 

Consular data are some of the most requested type of data via Freedom of Information requests. A more pro-active publication as open data would help bring efficiencies to the answering of such requests and potentially reduce the number of requests.

Add South Australia case study of 31% reduction in FOI.

_items.title: Diplomacy and trade
_items.body:
There is growing evidence that open data contributes to economic growth and trade by:

Opening up procurement data to help more small  businesses compete for opportunities:

Spend Network provides insight and analysis on public procurement and finance data to help suppliers identify opportunities to bid for government grants

Improving trade connections between countries

Labora is open data accelerator in Mexico- linking entrepreneurs working with open data to mentors, investors, data providers/regulators, and capacity building. With support of the UK Embassy and the Open Data Institute, the project has also facilitated exchanges between start-ups in UK and Mexico.

Helping businesses to comply with local and international regulations

Better Regulation Delivery Office, Ukraine- uses open data to create tools that give users access to information about regulations in just a few clicks, such as requirements to start a business

body: The FCO manages a lot of data, and the FCO is committed to going 'open by default'. But not all data should be made open. It is important for you to recognise what data can be made open and what data cannot. In this section, we explore principles which can help guide your decision of how you share data.
displayTitle: Supporting the FCO open data strategy
title: Supporting the FCO open data strategy

_items.title: Knowing the FCO commitments
_items.body:
The FCO has published its list of commitments to publishing open data, and an open data strategy which outlines some of the high priority datasets which should be available openly.

These have been selected based on utility to the FCO’s mission, and the PM’s Transparency Commitments of 2010-2011.

The list of datasets are regularly reviewed and added to. If the dataset in question is not listed, you should consider if the dataset could be open In accordance with the principle of ‘open by default’

_items.title: Knowing what data you have
_items.body:
When an organisation manages large volumes of data, it can be helpful to maintain a data inventory. Data inventories provide a full list of data assets collected and maintained by an organisation (whether they are open, shared, or closed). Maintaining and publishing a data inventory helps to:

  • Inform people about what types of data they can access from the FCO

  • Manage and organise your data assets

  • Comply with new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requirements around maintaining records of personal data and processing activities

HM Land Registry provides a open Dataset Inventory of all the electronic data held by Land Registry, including both internal (closed) and external (open) raw data.

_items.title: Knowing how widely the data can be shared
_items.body:
When deciding whether a dataset can be shared or made open - it can be helpful to map the datasets that you have on the Open Data Institute's ‘Data Spectrum’.

The data spectrum categories data into open/shared/closed based on who can be granted access to the dataset, and how they are permitted to use the data.

You can find out more about using the Data Spectrum in this article.

_items.title: Knowing how to move towards open
_items.body:
Some data can be made open without requiring changes. Other data might need to be changed before it can be published to ensure it doesn't contain sensitive data.

Such data might include:

  • Data of national security
  • Personal data
  • Commercially sensitive data 
  • Data that doesn't belong to the FCO
  • Data related to current investigations

You can explore each of these in more detail in the next part of the module.

body: In 2011, the UK government was a founding member of the Open Government Partnership (OGP). The OGP is an international platform for reformers committed to making their governments more open, accountable and responsive to citizens.
displayTitle: The pillars of an open government
title: The pillars of an open government
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body:
Transparency of information is the foundation of accountability in public services and open government.

"Transparency shines a light on underperformance and inefficiencies in public services. It allows citizens and the media to hold governments to account, strengthening civil society and building more open societies."

Freedom of Information (FoI) is central to transparency however pro-active publication of Open Data has the potential to deliver much wider benefits.

_items.title: Participation
_items.body:
Participation is about creating and using channels to solicit public feedback, and deepening public participation in developing, monitoring and evaluating government activities.

While Freedom of Information (FOI) can assist it is not sufficient to allow the public to engage fully. 

Factico is a mobile application developed in Mexico for citizens that allows them to highlight misconduct and provide feedback on failures in public services, such as electrical energy.

_items.title: Anti-corruption
_items.body:
Anti-corruption involves strengthening the rule of law and ensuring transparency in the management of public finances.It means establishing legal frameworks to publish information on the income and assets of high ranking public officials.

Increasingly, countries are taking steps to make beneficial ownership data open- that is, information on who controls and benefits from companies. This is important for exposing corruption, fraud, organised crime and tax evasion. 

Anti-corruption efforts are not just important in the UK but for any country who the UK chooses to do business with. 

Read more about the Global Declaration Against Corruption here.

_items.title: Technological innovation
_items.body:
Technology has had a profound effect on all aspects of our lives. It has changed the way governments deliver services and engage with citizens. 

As a result citizens now expect to be able to engage through advanced digital platforms that deliver more than just documents which would have previously been received in the post. 

Governments have a key role to play in both delivering and enabling others to build digital services and technological innovation.

body:
The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as a representative of the UK overseas, plays a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government. 

Open data helps FCO to:
displayTitle: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments
title: The role of the FCO in supporting open governments

_items.title: Raise global standards
_items.body:
In this era of digital diplomacy, open data helps FCO to raise global standards so that more information is available - for example through implementation of the Extractives Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). 

The EITI promotes transparency and better management of all steps along the value chain within the oil, gas and mining industries. This includes contracts and licensing, production, revenue collection, revenue allocation, and social and economic spending.

_items.title: Make all government data more open and transparent
_items.body:
The FCO plays an important role in supporting the capacity of governments to become more open and transparent. 

 For example, the UK Embassy in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) is working with a range of partners to strengthen the capacity for implementing open data in BiH, even within a constrained political environment.

Projects include producing an ‘open government’ guide for government and civil society representatives, supporting an open government working group leading advocacy efforts for BiH to join the OGP, and training civil servants from key Ministries to format and publish open data.

_items.title: increase transparency in UK aid flows
_items.body:
This allows people in developing countries to hold their governments to account for spending the aid effectively, while those people who give generously in the UK can see the impact their money makes.

For example, follow the money in Nigeria visualises and tracks government spending and international aid, and communicates aid effectiveness back to rural communities.

The International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) aims to improve the transparency of aid, development, and humanitarian resources and to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation activities.

body:
Not all data should be made open, especially where it contains sensitive data. If not treated sensitively, it can affect people's trust in data and in the responsible organisation.

There are legitimate reasons why some FCO data should not be published openly. Justifications may be made on the grounds of:
title: Dealing with sensitive data

_items.title: National security
_items.body:
Transparency sometimes needs to be balanced against national security issues. There may be good reason not to disclose information such as defence or security assets, or location and timing of counter-terrorism exercises, which could damage capabilities or effectiveness of UK operations.

For example, publishing diplomatic telegrams which contain intelligence information regarding an unfolding political coup or sensitive policy advice to ministers could put British Nationals in the Territory in question under risk.

_items.title: Privacy and confidentiality
_items.body:
Data containing personally identifiable information (PII) should not be released widely to protect individuals.

However data can be published the data has been suitably anonymised in accordance with privacy legislation and internationally recognised standards.

For example consular reports containing data about the location of pickpocketing and theft incidents reported at airports might contain PII. However, if the data is anonymised, it could be useful to understand spikes in petty crime activity in different areas.

You can find out more about anonymisation in this online guide, or by getting in touch with the UK Anonymisation Network (UKAN)

_items.title: Commercially or market sensitive data
_items.body:
Commercially or market sensitive data may be damaging to the UK government or to a commercial partner if improperly accessed. Much commercial data may be time sensitive, with the potential harm caused by disclosure diminishing over time. For example, the sensitivity of data relating to interest rates is likely to diminish in this way as time passes.

Data on future transactions regarding dealings in the extractives industry are widely regarded as commercially sensitive as disclosure to the public could cause actual harm.

_items.title: Intellectual property
_items.body:
Publishing data which is protected by copyright or database rights may not be permitted under law. It is important to determine what intellectual property rights exist in the data before you consider opening it and publishing under an open licence.

For example, Flickr photos on FCO embassy events might not be capable of sharing and re-use because they haven't been shared with an open licence.

_graphic.attribution: Photoroyalty - Freepik.com [CC-BY]

_items.title: Investigations
_items.body:
Data from investigations or civil or criminal proceedings could compromise public protection or enforcement activities, or prejudice court cases.

For example publishing the identify of persons being investigated for war crimes might put family members at risk.

body:
Open by default is the principle that everything should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal, ethical or otherwise harmful reason why it should remain closed. This principle is at the heart of an open government.

The represents a complete mind change for many who current take a demand led approach to the publication of open data.

Open by default is the first principle of the G8 Open Data Charter and the international Open Data Charter. 

The Canadian government is piloting an 'open by default' approach to releasing public sector information in four departments. The pilot promotes the proactive release of scientific and cultural research data which supports government transparency and accountability.
displayTitle: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda
title: Moving to an 'open by default' agenda

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
While transparency is a key pillar in an open government it is not the only one where open data can play a key role.

Current practices take a 'closed by default' approach where an 'open by default' approach would not only benefit transparency but also benefit the other pillars of an open government. 

The UK, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as a representative of the UK overseas, plays a critical role in demonstrating and promoting openness and transparency in government and helping lead the way.
title: Summary

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
At the heart of open government is open data. Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It must be free from restrictions and openly licensed.

Open data complements the work of the Freedom of Information (FOI) legislation through the proactive release of raw data.

Open data has multiple benefits:

  • Transparency and accountability
  • Improving services
  • Improving efficiency
  • Empowering citizen
title: Open data

_items.title: Citizen participation
_items.body:
Open data allows citizens to see inside the workings of government, to monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account over their commitments, and participate in decision-making. When citizens are empowered with information, they can also co-create solutions to improve their daily lives.

The Linida initiative, Indonesia, provides a platform to gather information on village assets and opportunities to improve socio-economic lives of villagers. Villagers use public information and produce their own data to engage with decision makers so that the local development policy and public service provision fulfil their priorities

The Participatory Monitoring Maputo platform, Mozambique- informs citizens about the need for proper waste removal and progress on waste removal, and aims to empower them to request services from the government through the use of a mobile app.

_items.title: Anti-corruption and fraud
_items.body:
The UK is committed to fighting corruption at home and abroad.  In 2016 the UK became the first country in the world to collect and publish who controls and benefits from companies in a structured format. Making data available on the beneficial owners of companies is important in the fight against corporate accountability.

Another way the UK government is tackling the perception of fraud is by publishing open data on government grant spending. In October 2017, the government introduced a platform allowing departments to share information on £100 billion worth of grants data from across government departments using a standard format developed by the 360Giving initiative.

Making contracting and procurement more transparent eg Paraguay is using open contracting to improve spending on education. Information about education contracts unearthed a wider spending scandal that triggered a formal investigation and citizen pressure and reform of school spending.

changing the behaviour of public officials to be less wasteful eg the Municipal Money open data portalwas launched in South Africa to inform citizens on their local authority’s financial performance and counter abuse of resources.

_items.title: Economic growth and trade
_items.body:
There is growing evidence that open data contributes to economic growth and trade by providing access to information on the business environment, and opening reducing information asymmetries so more small and medium businesses and compete for opportunities or enter new markets.

Publishing government grant opportunities can enable a more diverse group of SMEs and businesses to compete in the market eg Spend Network provides insight and analysis on public procurement and finance data to help suppliers identify opportunities to bid for government grants

Improving trade connections between countries eg Labora is open data accelerator in Mexico- linking entrepreneurs working with open data to mentors, investors, data providers/regulators, and capacity building. With support of the UK Embassy and the ODI, the project has also facilitated exchanges between start-ups in UK and Mexico.

Helping businesses to comply with local and international regulations eg Better Regulation Delivery Office, Ukraine- uses open data to create tools that give users access to information about regulations in just a few clicks, such as requirements to start a business

_items.title: Crisis management
_items.body:
Open data is a critical resource when responding to natural or manmade crises. In emergency situations or in resource-constrained environments, open data may be combined and enriched with other sources of data. In scenarios where government open data is not available, volunteers may fill the gap in data collection. In particular, the OpenStreetMap communitycontribute and maintain data about roads, trails, cafés, railway stations, and much more, all over the world.

Case studies

Open data can help in crisis management through:

facilitating information flows: Humanitarian actors, service providers and government agencies sharing data during Ebola outbreak to strengthen service delivery

monitoring risk and assessing needs: Use of OSM and combining sources of data during Nepal earthquake

Coordinating responses to disasters for greater efficiency of resources.

The FCO also makes use of a large amount of data and open data within internal activities, however challenges still exist in realising the benefits of a strong data strategy within the FCO.

Knowing what your commitments are as well as how to deal with sensitive data will  help maximise the benefit of all types of data both internally and externally.

In the next module we look more at the practical steps to get started with publishing sustainable open data.
